15.	Five-year Accident History
During the last five years, the facility had four near-miss incidents. MGC has completed incident investigations for each of the incidents and completed associated recommendations. 
Impact offsite receptors for the facility include schools, residences, recreational areas, and major commercial, office, or industrial areas.

9.	Management Of Change (MOC)
MGC has a written Management of Change process for the Covered Process to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or other employees whose tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to address the modifications. 

10.	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
MGC has a Pre-startup Safety Review program for the Covered Process. The facility performs Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications of the Covered Process. The reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation. A completed PSSR is required prior to introducing hazardous materials to the process.

11.	Compliance Audits
MGC conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP regulation are being implemented. The last compliance audit for the facility was completed in April 2021.

12.	Incident Investigation
MGC investigates incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of ammonia. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident, as well as corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. Incident Investigation reports related to the Covered Process are retained for a minimum of five years. 

13.	Employee Participation 
MGC has developed a written employee participation plan. MGC employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend measures for improvement.

4.	Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios
Information on the worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios is maintained in Section 5 of the facility RMP manual – Off-Site Consequence Analysis.

5.	Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA)
MGC conducted PHA studies to identify hazards associated with its Covered Process and review if appropriate controls were in place. The methodology used to carry out these analyses was “What If”. Studies undertaken by team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and were revalidated at least every five years. Findings and recommendations related to the PHAs were addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA for the Covered Process was completed in October 2019. 

6. Operating Procedures
MGC maintains written operating procedures to conduct activities in the Ammonia process safely. These procedures address various modes of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in these processes.

7.	Training 
MPCA has a training program for employees tasked with operational processes and procedures. Refresher training is provided at least once every three years. MGC maintains records of the training that has been provided to employees.

8.	Mechanical Integrity
MGC has a preventive maintenance program for the equipment in the Covered Process. MGC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Covered Process equipment examined by these checks includes, among others: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.

Risk Management Plant (RMP) Executive Summary – 5-year resubmission
MGC Pure Chemical America, Inc (MGC) is required to develop a RMP for the Anhydrous Ammonia Plat located in Mesa, Arizona hereafter referred to as the Ammonia process.
As required by 40 CFR 68.155, MGC developed this RMP Executive Summary for the Ammonia process.

1.	Facility and Regulated Substances
MGC has one regulated substance Anhydrous Ammonia at the Mesa facility. The facility uses anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide to create ultra-pure ammonium hydroxide. The facility is subject to the Program Level 3 RMP requirements. [The OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation also applies to the facility because the anhydrous ammonia onsite exceeds the PSM limit of 10,000 pounds.]
The following sections briefly describe the elements of the MGC release prevention program that are in place at its stationary source. 

2.	Emergency Action Plan
MGC complies with applicable federal, state, and local regulations related to emergency response plans. This facility has an emergency action plan that provides instructions to employees on how to respond to an emergency. Employees and contractors at the facility are trained in the key aspects of the emergency action plan. Employees and contractors are also informed of hazards in the workplace. Employees who work with potentially hazardous substances receive proper training.
MGC coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) so that the LEPC is aware of the Ammonia process and regulated substance and the emergency procedures proposed in the MGC Emergency Action Plan. MGC has provided a copy of the Emergency Response Plan to the following local agencies: 
•	City of Mesa Fire Dept. Headquarters
•	City of Mesa Police Dept
•	Mountain Vista Hospital
